description.narrative: The United Nations Development Programme Accelerator Labs are a new service offering that works with people, governments and private sector to reformulate development concept for XXI century.

sector.narrative: Eradicate poverty in all its forms and dimensions

condition.narrative: UNDP as the Implementing Partner will comply with the policies, procedures and practices of the United Nations Security Management System (UNSMS.)

comment.narrative: • 9 blogs published • 20 solutions mapped • 2 new sources of data • 2 methodologies and tools designed and used by projects of the Country Office and strategic partners • 2 methodologies scaled by projects of the Country Office and strategic partners. • 3 experiments sensed, explored, tested, and scaled by the Country Office and strategic partners.

Advance at Oct /2021
3 published blogs:  https://www.co.undp.org/content/colombia/es/home/Blog/2021/enero/reimagining-development-for-the-21st-century--accelerator-lab-in.html  https://www.co.undp.org/content/colombia/es/home/Blog/2021/Mayo/testing-out-new-ways-of-regional-development-in-colombia.html  https://medium.com/@undp.innovation/bringing-the-system-into-the-room-an-experience-from-colombia-b8329e1b0310
• 10 mapped solutions included at the global platform of the AccLabs Empathy Soltions : Paca Digestora, Econativa, Platos Comestibles, Homegenizador de panela, Bicicleta de carga (Vivero+Materas)
• 2 new sources of data o Real time data (Social Networks, web) through an artificial intelligence service (Citibeats) o Drone information to generate 3D models >> Dronedeploy + SketchUp
• 2 methodologies and tools adjusted, implemented or implemented with the accompaniment of Acclab that generate value for the CO and strategic allies
• The portfolio perspective has been included in the strategic projects (Yanama in La Guajira, Portfolio Design with Chora, Reactivation with USAID and Peace Corridors with Sweden) • Deepening the collaborative financing exercise, this time supporting the creation and launch of the UNDP crowdfunding platform: www.tuaporte.reactivacción.co • Horizontal Scanning (Fintech in Colombia)
• 2 scaled methodologies in CO projects and strategic allies o Collective Mapping of Solutions in Manizales o Empathy sessions (Guajira and Mojana empathy workshops)
• 3 experiments detected, explored, tested and escalated by the CO and strategic allies o An experiment to test the transmissibility was developed in partnership with the Universidad de los Andes o Drone for development in three uses cases: o Use of drones for crisis context: Enhancement of HBDA - Impact Mapping (Hurricane and floods) o Use of drones for reforestation mapping (Forests in Mojana) o Use of drones for Land Use Planning/management (Multipurpose Cadastre)
1 AccLab launching event in Colombia 1 Sensemaking exercise 1 Loop of an experiment 4 Blogs published

Taking advantage of the launch of the Human Development Report 2019 and that the administrator, Achim Steiner, was coming to Bogotá, we did the AccLab Soft Launch. This soft launch combines our first learning cycle (sensing, exploring and testing).
The Acc Lab is focusing on the last mile gap and how it could be reduced in a country suffering from deep economic and territorial asymmetries and inequalities. Our first intervention is this AUGMENTED DEVELOPMENT experience, designed as an experiment to identify and measure biases towards the “otherness”, in this case left-behind hotspots and their inhabitants. The point of departure will be identifying and tackling behaviors of exclusion by urban populations towards left behind territories and their populations.
Augmented Development is the tool and term coined by the Acc Lab Colombia to test adaptive behaviors by degrees of proximity, shedding light on how social norms and biases can evolve by getting closer to the unknown. This first version of the product will be used to bridge common citizens and left-behind peoples served by UNDP projects through immersive proximity. The stated hypothesis will be tested through a control study of the perspectives of participants and non-participants regarding left-behind hotspots. This forms part of the portfolio of experiments on hard-exclusion hotspots that AccLab is building.
In this augmented reality (AR) experience each participant had access to up to 10 pictures, each one of relevant UNDP projects: when a mobile device with the app points at the photograph, a video will be displayed which tells the human story behind the projects. this tool integrates local solutions, collective experience and experimentation. Control groups will have restraint or none exposure to AR or even to the pictures.
Because of time constraints we did not do the sensemaking exercise, which will be done at the beginning of 2020, as part of the strategic planning of the CO.
The process of writing blogs is taking us more than excepted which is why we only wrote one blog. We need to correct this and try to keep up with the monthly requirement of blogging.

• 7 blogs published • 2 tools designed and used by projects of the Country Office and strategic partners • 2 methodologies designed and used by projects of the Country Office and strategic partners • 3 experiments sensed, explored, tested, and scaled • 6 strategic partnerships created to run the experiments or strengthening the Country office internal capacity

• The AccLab has covered three topics with the blogs (The ole of Exploration; Life Helmets: a platform-based approach and Collective Solution Mapping), but we published five blogs overall because of their English and Spanish versions. Having the blogs in two languages is critical to reach a broader audience, work out loud, and share our knowledge with the network and other strategic allies. For example, we have shared our Life Helmets Strategy with stakeholders like Nesta and El Salvador, and the Maldives due to one of our blogs. We are currently writing our last two blogs of the year, one focused on behavioral science and crowdfunding and another about the AccLab learnings in 2020.
• In terms of methodologies, the AccLab has designed and implemented two different methodologies used by UNDP projects and the CO. 1. Portfolio Sensemaking: Chora Foundation and the Strategic Innovation Unit (SIU) from UNDP, with the help of the AccLab have been implementing a systemic approach to define a problem space in three territories of Colombia (la Guajira, Nariño y Antioquia). The aim is to build new capabilities within the CO and create a portfolio approach to engage different donors. This methodology is part of the deep demonstrations and pilots the SIU is implementing at the country level to promote UNDPs systemic transformation as an organization. 2. Collective Solution Mapping: This methodology aims to facilitate the exchange of data, information, and relevant knowledge to accelerate the fulfillment of the Sustainable Development Goals through the creation and management of learning communities with a emphasis on territory or sector.
• About the tools: 1. Strategy 2020+: This strategy aims to create and implement a collective, holistic, sustainable, and inclusive intention and strategic path for UNDP Colombia (2020-2024) that allows the CO to address the most vulnerable communities and the furthest left behind territories. The strategy is deployed in different phases. A diverse set was designed and used, such as, behavioral science, future thinking, human resources, collective work, and storytelling. This strategy is implented with the CO and is an iterative process that tests and improves the tools to create new ways of thinking and capabilities. 2. Within the methodology of Collective Solution Mapping, two tools are tested: A platform to collect and showcase the mappers communitys solutions and a form to create collective intelligence exercises.
• The Acclab run 3 experiments: 1. Life Helmets: Two nation-wide contests activated the ecosystem -Vice-presidency of Colombia, Santodomingo Foundation, the Colombian Industrial Association, the Colombian Plastic Association, the Makers Community, and EAN University- led to the open design of completely closed face shields that prevent cross-infection and self-infection by restraining access through cheeks and chin to the face. Life Helmets allowed UNDP to connect the dots between sectors with different ways of thinking and doing, which typically would not work together. Still, Life Helmets managed to unite under a common purpose: maintaining physical distancing during the COVID19 crisis while enabling economic activity to reactivate. The platform approach brought acceleration into each stage. Makers would build prototypes that would lead designers, companies and students to be inspired and multiply and revisit new models. The industry would move from there to producing at scale in no time. The Government could create enabling conditions from the beginning. All these elements moved smoothly and went from an idea to an industry adaptation in 8 weeks. Today, we are digging deep in three areas: The design and production of the face shields, the research and endorsement of the face shields, and the distribution and scalability of the face shields. 2. Augmented Development 2.0: An reloaded immersive experience that incorporates the use of augmented reality and communication tools to: o Create bridges and increase empathy levels between people, places, and actions taking place in the furthest left behind territories, to which we do not always have direct access. o Exercise transparency of entities on the expenditure of public resources. o Open spaces for discussion and provide communities with decision-making power on infrastructure projects in their territories by imaging such projects. 3. ReactivAcción: Is a collective financing strategy that invites citizens and the private sector to support microentrepreneurs in getting out of the COVID-19 crisis, generating employment, and reactivate the regional economy. This strategy seeks to alleviate the barriers experienced by small and medium-sized companies to access the financial system and offer a training program to strengthen business habits, digital appropriation, and financial education. The AccLab, through the use of Behavioral Sciences tools, seeks to motivate people to donate in the Colombian context.
• About the alliances: 1. We signed a DSA with the Santodomingo Foundation. 2. We created a platform-based partnership with the Government, academia, private sector, and community (Vice-presidency of Colombia, the Colombian Industrial Association, the Colombian Plastic Association, the Makers Community, and EAN University). 3. We have research alliances with renowned universities such as Yale and Andes University.
